This manual describes version 2.21.5 of mousetweaks and its graphical user interface consisting of the accessibility tab of the mouse control panel and two panel applets.
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the Mousetweaks application or this manual, please go to GNOME's Bugzilla, where where mousetweaks should soon be available.
Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the mousetweaks module (i.e.: mouse accessibility), its user interface or its manual, please use the facilities provided by the GNOME's Bugzilla, where the corresponding module should soon be available.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The mousetweaks module provides mouse accessibility enhancements for the GNOME Desktop. Indeed, it offers the following new functions to the user:

listitem.para: Simulated secondary click: it allows the user to perform a secondary click (menu click) by holding down the primary mouse button while keeping the pointer motionless.
Dwell click: it allows the user to perform the various clicks without pressing any hardware button.
Pointer capture: it allows the user to lock the pointer in a determined area of the panel until the user releases it by a predefined keystroke or mouse button.

sect2.title: Starting The Pointer Capture Function
sect2.para: As the pointer capture applet comes in the from of a panel applet, its starting method has to follow the rules dictated by the GNOME panel. Thus, to start the pointer capture function, you only have to install it on the panel and it will automatically run.

In order to add it to the panel, proceed as you do with any panel applet: perform a secondary click on the panel to open its contextual menu, choose Add to Panel, and you will get the window showing all the applets that can be installed on the GNOME panel.
Picture showing the Pointer Capture applet in the Add to Panel window
By double clicking on the Pointer Capture item in the Add to Panel window, the pointer capture applet will be added to the panel, and it will be working until removed.

sect1.title: Description Of The Functions
sect1.para: The Mousetweaks application offers three new pointer features to the user. These are:

sect2.title: Simulated Secondary Click Description
sect2.para: When the user activates this feature, he will be able to perform secondary clicks by using the primary mouse button. This is especially useful for users that have only one mouse button at their disposal.

sect3.title: How Does It Work?
sect3.para: When this feature is enabled, mousetweaks performs a secondary click at the location of the pointer, if the user keeps the primary mouse button pressed without moving the pointer for a determined time.
How long the user has to hold the primary mouse button pressed is determined by the delay slider under the activation checkbox:

textobject.para: Picture showing the slider to set how long to hold the primary button for the secondary click to be triggered

sect3.title: Differences To The Normal Secondary Click
sect3.para: As the simulated secondary click is not able to discard the mouse button down gesture from the primary button press of the user, it issues a primary click before issuing the secondary click. In other words, each secondary click performed by this function is immediately preceded by a primary click, and this makes it behave a bit differently to the normal secondary click performed by the secondary mouse button. For example:

listitem.para: It is not possible to perform a secondary click on multiple items because the primary click issued before the secondary click deselects the items.

When the simulated secondary click is performed on the trash icon on the panel, not only does the contextual menu appear, but the trash folder does also open. (The former is caused by the secondary click, the latter by the primary click preceding the right click.)

note.para: It is not possible to provide a list of all diverging behaviours, because it depends on the reaction of the application receiving the secondary click preceded by a primary click.

sect3.para: Some users may also be surprised by the consequences of the following: it is not possible to perform a long motionless primary button click and hold, without also triggering the secondary click. For example:

listitem.para: When doing a motionless primary button click and hold on the arrow of a scrollbar, the scrollbar jumps to the bottom after some time. This is in fact the normal behaviour of a secondary click on an arrow of a scrollbar.

tip.para: To work around this behaviour, simply move the pointer immediately after pressing the primary mouse button. This way the simulated secondary click is not issued.

sect2.title: Dwell Click Description
sect2.para: There are users that cannot use any hardware button. By activating the Dwell Click, they can have the mouse perform the various clicks without pressing any mouse button. The click types that can be performed are: single primary click, double-click, drag click and secondary click.

note.para: When the buttonless click is active, the mouse buttons remain functional and it is still possible to click with the mouse buttons.

sect3.title: Dwell Delay Setting
sect3.para: With the Delay slider, the user can configure how long the pointer has to be motionless for the click to be initiated.

textobject.para: Picture showing the delay slider of the dwell click

sect3.para: Details about how to complete the click and how to choose the click type can be found under How To Complete Clicks And Specify The Click Type.

note.para: The dwell delay only works in the context of the dwell click.

sect3.title: Motion Treshold Setting
sect3.para: For people that have trouble to keep the mouse motionless, there is the Motion Treshold slider.

textobject.para: Picture showing the motion treshold slider of the dwell click

sect3.para: When the slider is set towards low, even little mouse movements are considered; however, by setting a higher treshold, the mouse has to traverse a bigger distance before it is considered as moving.

note.para: This function only works in the context of the dwell click.

sect3.title: How To Complete Clicks And Specify The Click Type
sect3.para: Each time she pointer stops moving, a click is initiated. How the click is completed and how the click type is chosen depends on what dwell mode the user has selected. The two available modes are:

textobject.para: Picture showing the radio buttons to select dwell mode

sect3.para: To select the mode, the user only has to click on the radio button that corresponds to his choice.

sect4.title: Dwell Click With Automatic Click Completion And Click Type Choice Beforehand
sect4.para: This mode is active when the user selects Choose type of click beforehand. In fact, after the mouse has been motionless for the time defined by the Delay slider, the system will automatically perform the click type that is selected in the Click Type Window shown here:

textobject.para: Picture showing the click type window

sect4.para: To display the click type window on the screen, the user has to put a checkmark in the checkbox named Show click type window:

textobject.para: Picture with the checkbox to display the click type window

sect4.para: After the click has occurred, the single click type will be automatically restored. In order to choose another click type, the user has to perform an automatic click on the button in the Click Type Window that corresponds to its click type choice.
Some users might prefer to use the Dwell Click panel applet instead of the Click Type Window. The advantage of the panel applet is that it does not cover any open window on the desktop.

textobject.para: Picture showing the click type applet at the right of the gnome menus

sect4.para: To display the click type applet on the GNOME panel, please follow the procedure you have to use in order to add any applet to the GNOME panel. If you do not know how to add an applet to the panel, have a look at Starting The Pointer Capture Function.
The click type window and the click type applet can be used simultaneously or each on its own.

sect4.title: Dwell Click With Click Type Choice And Click Completion By A Mouse Gesture
sect4.para: This mode is active when the user selects Choose type of click with mouse gestures. In fact, after the mouse has been motionless for the above predefined delay, the shape of the pointer will change for a little while:

listitem.para: If the user moves the mouse while it is showing the alternative shape, a click is performed and the pointer returns to its normal shape. The type of click performed depends on the direction of the movement of the mouse.

If the user keeps the mouse motionless until the pointer returns to its normal shape, the user can move the mouse without a click being performed. The next dwell click can be performed when the mouse stops moving again.

sect4.para: The user also has the possibility to match click type with movement direction by using the 4 popups available under this mode:

textobject.para: Picture showing the configuration options to map click type to movement direction

sect4.para: There is also a Disabled menu item in each popup. The user can select it if he does not want some click types to be performed automatically. This is especially interesting for users that have problems only with certain click types.

sect2.title: Locking The Pointer Description
sect2.para: There are people that have to use their pointing device not only for the computer. These people would welcome a way to lock the pointer into an area of the screen, so that they can use their pointing device for other tasks.
In fact, the Pointer Capture panel applet creates such an area on the panel, into which the user can lock the pointer until he releases it in a determined way.
sect2.remark: Have a look at Starting The Pointer Capture Function for instructions about how to install the pointer capture applet on the GNOME panel.

textobject.para: Picture showing the pointer capture area (green) with its contextual menu
Picture of the pointer capture area when the pointer has been captured

sect2.para: By choosing Preferences in the contextual menu of the pointer capture applet, the user gets a window with the options of the pointer capture applet:

textobject.para: Picture showing the preferences of the pointer capture applet

sect2.para: The preferences window of the pointer capture applet has three sections:

listitem.para: In the Capture Pointer section, the user can specify under what circumstances the pointer gets captured when it moves into the capture area. For example: if the control modifier is checked, the pointer gets captured when it is over the capture area and the user presses the Control modifier key. If no modifier is checked and the mouse button is set to 0, the pointer only has to move into the capture area to get locked.
It is also possible to specify a combination of modifiers and mouse button.
In the Release Pointer section, the user can specify what modifier or mouse button releases the pointer.
It is also possible to specify a combination of modifiers and mouse button.
In the Size of Capture Area section, the user can specify the width of the capture area on the GNOME panel.

sect2.title: Authors and hosting site
sect2.para: Mousetweaks is based on a specification hosted on Launchpad. It was implemented by Gerd Kohlberger ( gerdk@svn.gnome.org ), while I ( frfumanti@svn.gnome.org ) helped with testing and other things.
You can find more informations about Mousetweaks on Launchpad and on GNOME Live.
